comments.commentBody: and these cops should be trained on disarming without shooting and killing people if they do not have a gun. A mentally ill man was shot and killed in Milton MA because he was armed with a pen and the cop claimed he lunged at him. He shot and killed him. I probably could have disarmed this mentally ill man who had a ballpoint pen.  I was married to a trooper who used to show me photos of the prisoners in their cells who were cuffed and "smacked around" by the cops on duty. He found it amusing. Half of them are on power trips and are very abusive. I do have the evidence on it .

So, as a white person you have suffered injustice at the hands of the police, but somehow, the chokehold is... OK?  Because Garner was a big black man?  It's amazing to me that nowhere do you say, when you talk about being treated badly by cops, that your civil rights were violated, which seems to be what the sidebar is here.  So if cops have given you a raw deal despite the fact that you're white, why would you also assume that the policing you describe is best for the situation you also describe?  Clearly, the cops we're talking about are, at best, poorly trained.  Doesn't every citizen deserve the best-trained cops that money can buy?  After all, it's your (our) money that's buying.
Maybe send the NYPD out there?

Mondy: it would seem to me the very fact that the chokehold has been banned for use by the NYPD since 1993, and that Pantaleo used it *anyway* should be close to prima facie case of negligence. Simply reading the NYPD rulebook to the Grand Jury would do the trick. While Pantaleo *claimed* that he learned the hold in the police academy, ignorance of the law, or of department policy, is, as they say, no excuse.

I remember once reading that people had not domesticated rice. Rice had domesticated people.

The rice grown for consumption by most of the world today and for thousands of years would not exist without the propogation of seedlings, careful planting and constant irrigation supplied by it's 'serfs'.

The people who depended on the rice for most of their calories would not have developed their cooperative society if it were not for the nature of the rice.

Just a thought.

Hmm. Wheat-growers versus rice growers. I am not sure how far I could go (or we could go) if I (we) got on top of this horse. Imagine whisking some wheat-growing serfs from 12th century England to the 21st century social psychology lab and seeing what color pens they would pick. I bet they would all pick the same colored ones, because in feudal society standing out was not a good thing to do.

It is usually very hard to define what exactly cultural factors like this are. For example, articles like this reinforce NYTimes readers' subjective assumptions that Americans are individualistic, but an objective measure of individualism may be hard, even impossible, to discover.

I agree. I'd like to see the rates in the rise of family violence and murder/suicides in couples who are miserably married. I'll bet it's higher...but then am I attempting to address the elephant in the room here?

I agree that declining divorce rates may partly be due to financial difficulties in separating, rather than concluding that marriages are stronger and more resilient.  Many couples are unable to afford divorce lawyers, and unable to afford separate residences.  This is not exactly a happy trend...
In reply to "Human Being":  You make many excellent points.  The use of the chokehold is truly problematic, whether intentional or not.  And how long it was applied was the most disturbing element.

Frank Zappa said it best in 1965: "You know, people; I'm not black, but there's a whole lotta times I wish I could say I'm not white."

[Lyric from "Trouble Every Day," a song commenting on the Watts riots]

So if the injustice is continuous, violates your rights, is abusive and physically harmful you, just sit there and take it regardless of the authority figure, a priest, police officers, school authority. We have a history of punishing the whistle blowers, so filing a complaint is an invitation to more abuse and harassment. Unless you can enough wealth to hire lawyers to protect your rights and attempt to get justice.

I don't know what school you attended in first grade but i do not recall this civic lesson. I was taught the police were there to protect and serve. Yes it's simple, we have a broken system here. We are not doing ourselves any favors by ignoring it. Sometimes we can not shut up if we wish to preserve our rights. This man did not respond violently to the officers. He try to talk his way out of a ticket. There is no excuse for this over reaction. Any reasonable person would come to this conclusion viewing the video.

Did you not watch the video where he was choked? He did have his hands in the air when they tackled him to the ground. He was telling them not to touch him and trying to avoid them, but his hands were in the air. He was being harassed for a crime he did not commit and that they had no proof of. Whatever happened to innocent until proven guilty? Their actions were discriminatory and the resulting overzealous actions of the police killed this man over what would have been a misdemeanor IF they could prove he had committed any crime. Don't defend these cops' unnecessary violence. That perpetuates the problem. There is no solution in making excuses for them.
The cop in question has been on "modified duty" since July 17.
They still might rough you up, though. Beat you. Shoot you. Assault you. It's happened before, I dare say it will happen again.

those things you mention have very little to do with each other. The six billion for Ebola isn't coming out of DHS funds at the discretion of the president, its a special funding request to Congress. And honestly, it's not only warranted but overdue.

If Coast Guard helicopter rescue is being cut its because that's what DHS deemed a warranted cut to fit within the funding Congress gave them in the last budget, most likely.You could argue that's a poor choice, but its not like Obama or anyone said "lets cut helicopter rescue to fund Ebola,"even implicitly. The federal government is a sprawling bureaucracy with many departments and programs...

Hmm. I wonder how filing a complaint with Bull Conner would've gone down? Wait, I think I remember lots of citizens at the Edmund Pettus bridge filling out complaint forms, so I guess it all good, right?
WOW! That was really fun! Left it at WORRIED - DESIRED - GANDERS, but was seeing more. I do anagrams regularly but inside a crossword? Impressive. Thanks for the Schrodinger info; didn't know that.

Inequality is to civics a bit like what melting the icecaps is to climate: it makes societies and the economies much, much more radically unstable.

Concentration of wealth gave us huge recessions at the end of the 19th century and the beginning of the 20th century. It also gave us the Great Depression and the Great Recession. In between we had the S&L crisis and Black Friday during Reagan's time.

It also creates deflationary recessions. The rich don't mind deflationary recessions, but to the public, an inflationary one can be fixed by tweeking monetary policy while a deflationary one is a bit like what happens to an airplane when it stalls in the air: it is extremely difficult to recover from.

Inequality amplifies the bad and (only temporarily) exaggerates the good (which turns out to be bad).

Susan Howe.
Without question.
(Small press, but what significant poetry
does not emerge from small presses these days...?)
Thrilled to be an "unnotable" book for the fifth straight time.

Although I appreciate Dem NYC's first sentence, my primary purpose for the posting was, as with many other Commenters, to make people aware of Eric Lichtblau's "captivating book".

Perhaps I should have written more accurately something like "Equally Pre-Stratified Top 100 List" as The Times apparently chose 50 books in Fiction & Poetry and 50 in Nonfiction instead of post-stratifying a Top-100 list, which would very likely not have the same number of books in each of the two strata.

If such were the case, then I would probably agree with the second sentence in Dem NYC's posting...

About seventeen years ago, I worked in the neighborhood now called Hudson Square.  There was one young beat cop who walked the streets in the neighborhood.  He knew everyone who worked there and greeted many of us daily. He also knew who didn't belong in the neighborhood.  He was an effective (and kind) policeman.  In fact, I wrote a letter of recommendation to his supervisor, something I've never done before, or since.  When police are part of a community, they understand its flows and know the people who live and work there.  That's ultimately what makes a community and its citizens safe.   My opinion of the police has changed radically after several more recent encounters.  Many of the officers are overly aggressive, to the point of being frightening.  It's going to take more than simply moving police away from street stops and marijuana arrests to change their image.  The police must return to community policing, and protecting and serving its citizens, rather than themselves.
Not anymore. The ACA removed caps and the insurance company can't drop you when you get sick either.

Your logic is both strained and misapplied. It makes no difference if 5 policeman did not wake up that morning saying 'today I will kill someone.' The CEO of a tanaka airbags did not start his day saying z'today, I will make an airbag explode with shrapnel and decapitate a driver.' But I assure you, he and his company will be found criminally liable for the injuries they caused.
This is an absolute shame!  The police should not be above the law- they should be held accountable for their actions!

I've always enjoyed walking, but feel adding a pedometer is a useful plus. I use it to gauge my "aerobic" steps.

For those times when I am unable to do my average number of steps, I try and add on a bit more when I have the opportunity. It has been 3 1/2 years since I added the pedometer and I've averaged more steps each year.

Adding stairs and hills along with picking up the pace is worth considering, if possible. It is much easier to keep going when it becomes routine.

Good point about walking being a reasonable form of locomotion -- and you don't get a runner's high and think you own the road and can run through a truck. You can also observe the environment, reflect and interact with others. Running, you are largely in your own world, zooming through the wider world the walker can better appreciate.

Running, in our species, is mainly for escaping danger, so it is good to keep this survival skill somewhat intact. But at some point we have to admit running is for the younger folk. They are, after all, as Seinfeld has reminded us, our replacements.

Figuring out whether running or walking is the better way to keep fit as one ages - past 60, or 70, depends on experience, preference, and access to places to walk or run. I'm 72. I live in an urban neighborhood (Cambridge, MA). I can and do walk every day weather permitting. Steady rain, uncleared snowy/icy sidewalks, or enervating summer heat are the only impediments.
Years ago I tried jogging and didn't like it. It also has to be undertaken as a form of deliberate exercise, as opposed to walking, which is a reasonable form of locomotion and can be combined with public transport as needed.
A few years ago I got a simple pedometer that I put in my pocket in the morning and take out at night. Most days I walk about 10,000 steps, plus or minus. I like to walk fast. A childhood in NYC with a long legged father, himself a New Yorker set my pace. and I often pass other pedestrians, most of whom are younger than me. My pedometer measures the speed of my pace and at the end of a week about 30 to 40% of my steps are "aerobic." I don't think I would do better if I put on running shoes and jogged. I'd have to make some kind of circle and have to come home to change my clothing. With walking I can just keep going about my business. I have found that the more I walk, the more I can walk and without pain or fatigue or boredom. I don't pollute the air with my car, either. None of us is getting out of this world alive. Walking is a good way to stay on my feet and see the world.
But most of the rice is grown in the redder parts of the state.
California rice is the lowest in arsenic however, perhaps due to a more progressive, environmentally friendly approach to land management? I guess that would be a shallow stereotype as well.

Your point is well-noted, but remember that rice in the US has historically been a plantation crop. Plantation-style production is, as should be obvious with a bit of consideration, the worst of all types of production from a socio-political development perspective.

The author's point has nothing much to do with the type of crop and everything to do with the mode and requirements of smallholder production.

We do produce a lot of rice though. One of the top five exporters in the world. And the three states that produce the most are Arkansas, California and Louisiana.  So rice is obviously what progressives and tea party types both produce. Of course, that would be a shallow stereotype, wouldn't it?
